title: Go
description: A general-purpose Go quick reference covering syntax, functions, packages/modules, common pitfalls, and day-to-day patterns.

categories.title: Installation and Tooling
categories.description: Core Go toolchain commands for building, testing, and managing modules.

items.title: Go toolchain essentials
items.description: Most Go work flows through the go command.

rows: Build and run the current module
Run tests with the race detector
Add a module to the workspace
Install a tool binary at a version

items.example:
go mod init example.com/hello

go fmt ./...

go test ./...

go test -race ./...

categories.title: Basic Functionality
categories.description: Core syntax: packages, imports, variables, types, strings, and output.

items.title: Program structure
items.description: Go code is organized into packages. The entry point is main.main().

rows: Exported identifiers start with a capital letter

items.title: Variables, constants, and types
items.description: Go is statically typed with type inference.
items.example:
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
	var name string = "Ada"
	age := 36
	const active = true
	f := 3.9
	n := int(f)
	fmt.Println(name, age, active, n)
}

items.title: Strings and runes
items.description: Strings are byte slices; iterate runes for Unicode code points.

categories.title: Functions
categories.description: Parameters, returns, scope, anonymous functions, and commonly used built-ins.

items.title: Parameters and returns
items.description: Go supports multiple return values and named returns.

items.title: Scope and closures
items.description: Functions can close over variables from outer scope.

items.title: Anonymous functions
items.description: Often used with goroutines, callbacks, or small one-off logic.

items.title: Built-in / predefined functions (common)
items.description: A small sampling of frequently used built-ins.

rows: Allocate zeroed value and return pointer
Delete a key from a map

items.example:
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
	s := make([]int, 0, 3)
	s = append(s, 1, 2, 3)
	fmt.Println(len(s), cap(s))
}

items.title: Filter a slice
items.description: Idiomatic filtering uses a loop (or a small helper).

rows: Simplest and fastest in most cases

items.title: Parse and validate input
items.description: Use strconv for numeric parsing and strings.TrimSpace for basic sanitation.
items.example:
package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"regexp"
	"strconv"
	"strings"
)

func main() {
	s := strings.TrimSpace(" 123 " )
	n, err := strconv.Atoi(s)
	fmt.Println(n, err)

email := "a@example.com"
ok, _ := regexp.MatchString(`^[^@]+@[^@]+$`, email)
	fmt.Println(ok)
}

items.title: Package-level state
items.description: Globals are package-level identifiers. Prefer dependency injection for testability.

categories.title: Packages/Modules
categories.description: How Go organizes code and dependencies.

items.title: Modules and go.mod
items.description: Modules are the unit of dependency versioning.
items.example:
go mod init example.com/myapp
go get github.com/google/uuid@latest
go mod tidy

items.title: Imports and packages
items.description: Import paths are module path + directory. Package name is declared in source.

items.title: Arithmetic, comparison, logical, bitwise
items.description: Use == for value equality; there is no operator overloading.

categories.title: Common Errors
categories.description: Frequent pitfalls and how to recognize them.

items.title: Typical compile/runtime errors

rows: panic: runtime error: invalid memory address
Map writes from multiple goroutines without sync
Wrong layout string (Go uses reference time)
Typed-nil in an interface (var e *T = nil; var err error = e)

categories.title: Arrays
categories.description: Arrays are fixed-length; slices are the more common dynamic view over arrays.

items.title: Arrays vs slices

rows: Array: length is part of the type
Slice: length can change; references backing array

items.title: Maps
items.description: Maps are reference types; iteration order is randomized.

categories.title: Loops
categories.description: Go only has one looping keyword: for.

items.title: for / range

categories.title: Conditions
categories.description: Branching with if/switch and type switches.

items.title: if / switch / type switch
items.description: if can include a short statement; switch can omit a tag to behave like if/else chains.

categories.title: Regular Expressions
categories.description: The regexp package implements RE2 syntax (no backtracking).

items.title: regexp basics

rows: Compile pattern and panic on error

categories.title: Date and Time
categories.description: Use the time package. Remember: layouts use the reference time 2006-01-02 15:04:05.

items.title: time essentials

categories.title: Database Interactions
categories.description: Use database/sql with prepared statements. You must import a driver for your database.

items.title: database/sql essentials
items.description: Drivers register themselves via blank imports. Always close rows and use context in servers.

categories.title: Extras: Error Handling
categories.description: Go uses explicit error returns and favors wrapping with %w.

items.title: Errors, wrapping, and checks
Goroutines and channels
items.description: Use channels and sync primitives to coordinate; use context for cancellation.

items.title: Structs, methods, interfaces

rows: type User struct { ID int; Name string }

items.title: Marshal and Unmarshal
items.description: Use struct tags to map JSON field names.

categories.title: Extras: Testing
categories.description: How to run tests and common patterns.

items.title: go test essentials
items.description: Table-driven tests are idiomatic.
